page.title: 08THE PIGGERY
page.content: Few farms keep pigs now and breeding and rearing is concentrated in a few small areas of the country. There is a{PIGGERY}at Muir of Pert which forms part of a larger pig rearing business in Scotland. The piggery uses part of the disused airfield and there are 250 sows and 20 boars. These pigs are kept purely for breeding. No pigs are bought in. This prevents the spread of disease. Breeding is done using artificial insemination and pigs are kept inside all year round. A sow produces about 10 piglets per litter and there is an average of 2.3 litters per year. At about 2 months old the piglets are sent to replace any needed at the other piggery at Crail in Fife. Some may be sold for fattening and slaughter.
